II. Part B

E. Knowledge and comprehension type of questions (viz., Recognizing and recalling information including dates, events, persons, places, terms, definition, facts, principles, theories, methods, procedures , reasons, problems, etc.,)

3.0 Marks

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

Answer Key

E1.

What do you understand by pump? Give the classification of pump

A pump is a mechanical device which converts the mechanical energy into hydraulic energy. The hydraulic energy is in the form of pressure energy. When a pump is interposed in a pipeline, it converts energy from an external source into hydraulic energy and transfers this energy to the liquid through the pipeline. The pumps are generally used for lifting liquid., from a lower level to a higher level. Pumps are also used to increase the pressure energy without lifting the liquid i.e., tit* potential energy is unchanged.

CLASSIFICATION OF PUMPS

Pumps are usually classified into two types:

(i) Positive-displacement pumps

(ii) Rotodynamic or Rotary pumps

The reciprocating pumps are again classified as:

(i) Single acting pump

(ii) Double acting pump.

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

E2.

Write basic difference between Positive-displacement pumps and Rotodynamic or Rotary pumps

Positive-displacement pumps

Positive-displacement pumps are those pumps in which the liquid is sucked and then it is pushed due to the thrust exerted on it by a piston. These pumps have one or more cylinder which are alternatively filled with the liquid and emptied. The most common example of the positive displacement pump is the reciprocating pump.

Rotodynamic or Rotary pumps

Rotodynamic pumps have a rotating element, through which, as the liquid passes its angular momentum changes, due to which the pressure energy of the liquid is increased. The centrifugal pump is a rotodynamic pump.

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

E3.

Write short on MULTI-STAGE PUMPS

If a centrifugal pump consists of two or more identical impellers mounted on the same shaft and are enclosed in the same casing, it is known as multi-stage centrifugal pump. Normally a pump with a single impeller is suitable for a manometric head upto 100 m. But if the liquid is required to be delivered against a still larger head, multi-stage pumps are used. In multi-stage pumps, all the impellers are connected in series so that discharge from the first impeller is guided into the inlet of the second impeller and so on till the required head is obtained. The stage of the pump is equal to the number of impellers.

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

E4.

Write about working of JET PUMP

A jet pump is a simple device which uses high pressure water. Jet pump consists of a pipe having throat at its bottom. The upper end of the pipe leads to the required height. When the high pressure water is forced through the nozzle at the throat, it creates a suction pressure in the main pipe. Because of the pressure difference between the throat and the sump level, the water is lifted up. The lifted water after coming in contact with the high pressure jet is carried into the delivery pipe. The pumping continues till the supply of the high pressure water is maintained. Jet pumps are generally used in construction work for dewatering trenches and mines. These are also sometimes used to feed steam boilers. However, in this case, high pressure steam is used instead of high pressure water.

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

E5.

What do you understand by slip? Also explain negative slip

Slip of a pump is defined as the difference between the theoretical discharge and actual discharge of the pump. In practice, it is found that the actual discharge (Qa) is less than the theoretical discharge (Qth). Thus slip of the pump is positive.

Slip= Qth- Qa

When the delivery valve opens before the suction stroke is completed, the actual discharge is more than the theoretical discharge. In such cases, the slip of the pump is known as negative slip. Negative slip occurs when the delivery pipe is short, suction pipe is long and pump is running at high speed.

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

E6.

List out the precautions to prevent the occurrence of separation

The following precautions should be taken to prevent the occurrence of separation.

a. The pump should not run too fast.

b. The suction pressure inside the cylinder should not exceed the permissible limit.

c. Air vessels should be provided both on the suction and the delivery sides.

d. The suction lift should not be increased beyond the permissible limit.

e. The lengths of the suction and delivery pipes should not exceed the requirements.

f. The diameters of the suction and delivery pipes should not be reduced below the designed values.

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

E7.

Write about working of Hydraulic ram

Hydraulic is a closed chamber having compressed air in the top portion and the water at the bottom. At the base of the chamber there is an opening through which water may flow in to the vessel or out from the vessel.

Working : During the first half of delivery stroke, the piston moves with acceleration and forces the water into the delivery pipe with a velocity more than the mean velocity. The quantity of water in excess of the mean discharge will flow into, in vessel. During second half of delivery stroke, the piston moves with retardation and velocity of water in the delivery pipe is less than the mean velocity. The water already stored in the air vessel will start flowing into the delivery pipe. Hence, the rate of flow of water in the delivery pipe, beyond the air vessel, will be uniform.

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

E8.

Write about Volute casing

Volute Casing: It is a spiral shape casing which surrounds the impeller. As shown if Fig., the shape of casing is such that area of flow gradually increases from the impeller outlet to the delivery pipe. Thus the kinetic energy is converted into the pressure energy

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

E9.

Write about Vortex casing

Vortex Casing: If a circular chamber is provided between the impeller and the volute chamber as shown if Fig., the casing is known as vortex casing. The circular chamber is also known as whirlpool chamber. In this type of casing, the loss of energy due to the formation of eddies is reduced to a considerable extent.

( Vertex chamber Volute chamber )

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

E10.

Write about Casing with guide blades

Casing with Guides Blades: In this type of casing, impeller is surrounded by a series of guide blades mounted on a ring as shown in Fig. The liquid leaving the impeller passes through the passage between the guide vanes. The passage has a gradually increasing area, thus reducing the velocity of flow through guide vanes and consequently increasing the pressure of liquid

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

E11.

Write short notes on Deep well pump (or) Bore hole pump

This is multi-stage pump, the -number of stages depending upon the head required. This is generally used for pumping water from depths greater than 8 m. It consists of a large diameter pipe extending from the bottom of well to the top. At the bottom is fixed a strainer with foot valve. Above it, a series of impellers are fixed one above the other for multistage action. These impellers are all fixed to a common shaft which is extended from them to the top of the well where it is connected to an electric motor. Sometimes, the pump; is driven by a prime mover, generally a diesel engine. In such cases a belt drive is employed for small and medium sized pumps and toothed gearing for larger sizes. In some types, the electric motor is fixed right above or below the impellers and are made water proof by suitable covering.

E12.

Write any three differences between centrifugal pump and reciprocating pump

S.No.

Centrifugal Pump

Reciprocating Pump

1.

Its discharging capacity is high

It can handle relatively small quantity of liquid.

2.

It is used for lifting highly viscous liquids such as oils, muddy and sewage water, paper pule etc.

It can handle only pure water or less viscous liquids free from impurities.

3.

It can be operated at very high speeds

It can be operated at low speeds only

F. Short Notes, Brief Answers and Derivaitions etc., (At least two problems may be included from unit of the syllabus)

6.0 Marks

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

Answer Key

F1.

Write the classification of pumps

Pumps are usually classified into two types:

(i) Positive-displacement pumps

(ii) Rotodynamic or Rotary pumps

Positive-displacement pumps

Positive-displacement pumps are those pumps in which the liquid is sucked and then it is pushed due to the thrust exerted on it by a piston. These pumps have one or more cylinder which are alternatively filled with the liquid and emptied. The most common example of the positive displacement pump is the reciprocating pump.

Rotodynamic or Rotary pumps

Rotodynamic pumps have a rotating element, through which, as the liquid passes its angular momentum changes, due to which the pressure energy of the liquid is increased. The centrifugal pump is a rotodynamic pump.

The reciprocating pumps are again classified as:

(iii) Single acting pump

(iv) Double acting pump.

If the liquid is in contact with one side of the piston, it is known as single acting pump. On the other hand, if the liquid is in contact with both sides of the piston, it is known as double acting pump.

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

F2.

Enumerate the working of a single-acting reciprocating pump with a line diagram

Fig shows a single acting reciprocating pump, which consists of a piston which moves to and fro in a close fitting cylinder. The movement of the piston is obtained by connecting the piston to crank by means of a connecting rod. The crank is rotated at uniform speed by a motor. The cylinder is connected to suction and delivery pipes, which are provided with one way valves. A suction pipe is a pipe which connects the source of and the cylinder, whereas a delivery pipe is pipe into which water is discharged from the cylinder. The function of one-way valve is to allow the water in one direction only.

Fig. Single Acting Reciprocating Pump

When crank starts rotating, the piston moves to and fro in the cylinder. When the crank is at Ao, the piston is at tin extreme left position in the cylinder. As the crank is rotating from Ao to Co the piston moves towards right and a vacuum is created on the left side of the piston. But, the pressure acting on the liquid surface in the sump is the atmospheric pressure. Thus there is a pressure difference in the liquid at the two ends of the suction pipe and the liquid is forced in to the suction pipe from the sump. The one-way valve in the suction pipe opens and the liquid fills the cylinder.

When crank is rotating from Co to Ao, the piston moves from its extreme right position towards left. The movements of the piston towards left increases the pressure of the liquid inside the cylinder more than atmospheric pressure. Hence, delivery valve opens and the liquid is forced into the delivery pipe and is raised to a required height. At the end of this stroke, the crank is at Ao, so, that it has completed one cycle. The same cycle is repeated as the crank rotates. This is the working principle of a single acting reciprocating pump.

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

F3.

Write different types of casings adopted in centrifugal pump?

Casing: It is an airtight chamber covering the impeller. It is designed such that the kinetic energy of the liquid discharged at the outlet of the impeller is converted into pressure energy before the water leaves the casing. The different type of casings that are commonly adopted are:

(a) Volute casing (b) Vortex casing

(c) Casing with guide blades

Fig. Volute casing

(a) Volute Casing: It is a spiral shape casing which surrounds the impeller. As shown if Fig., the shape of casing is such that area of flow gradually increases from the impeller outlet to the delivery pipe. Thus the kinetic energy is converted into the pressure energy

( Vertex chamber Volute chamber )(b) Vortex Casing: If a circular chamber is provided between the impeller and the volute chamber as shown if Fig., the casing is known as vortex casing. The circular chamber is also known as whirlpool chamber. In this type of casing, the loss of energy due to the formation of eddies is reduced to a considerable extent.

Fig. Vortex casing

(c) Casing with Guides Blades: In this type of casing, impeller is surrounded by a series of guide blades mounted on a ring as shown in Fig. The liquid leaving the impeller passes through the passage between the guide vanes. The passage has a gradually increasing area, thus reducing the velocity of flow through guide vanes and consequently increasing the pressure of liquid

Fig. Casing with guide blade

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

F4.

Enumerate the working of a double acting reciprocating pump with a line diagram

Working of a double-acting reciprocating pump

Fig. Double Acting Reciprocating Pump

As shown in Fig. a double acting reciprocating pump li,14 two suction and two delivery pipes with appropriate valves. In double acting pump, the suction and delivery strokes occur., simultaneously

When the crank rotates from Ao to Co, a vacuum is created on the left side of the piston and the liquid is sucked through the suction pipe S1. At the same time, the liquid on the right side of the piston is pressed and a high pressure causes the delivery valve B to open and the liquid flows into the delivery pipe D2.

When the crank rotates from Co to Ao the liquid is sucked through the suction pipe S2 and delivered through the delivery pipe D1. When the crank reaches A, the piston is in the extreme left position. Thus one cycle is completed. As the crank rotates, the cycles are repeated. Because of continuous delivery strokes in double acting pump, it gives more uniform discharge than a single-acting pump.

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

F5.

Explain the slip and separation of reciprocating pump

Slip of a pump is defined as the difference between the theoretical discharge and actual discharge of the pump. In practice, it is found that the actual discharge (Qa) is less than the theoretical discharge (Qth). Thus slip of the pump is positive.

Slip= Qth- Qa

But slip is mostly expressed as percentage slip which is given by,

Percentage slip =

In some cases, when the delivery valve opens before the suction stroke is completed, the actual discharge is more than the theoretical discharge. In such cases, the slip of the pump is known as negative slip. Negative slip occurs when the delivery pipe is short, suction pipe is long and pump is running at high speed.

Separation of reciprocating pump is that phenomenon by which the steady and continuous flow of liquid obstructed due to the presence of air and dissolved gases in the flowing liquid. If the absolute pressure falls below 2.5 m of water, the dissolved gases will start appearing in the liquid and continuous flow will be obstructed.

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

F6.

With a neat figure explain the working of hydraulic ram

Hydraulic is a closed chamber having compressed air in the top portion and the water at the bottom. At the base of the chamber there is an opening through which water may flow in to the vessel or out from the vessel. An air vessel is fitted to the suction and delivery pipes at a point close to the cylinder of a single-acting reciprocating pump.

Fig. Hydraulic ram

Working : During the first half of delivery stroke, the piston moves with acceleration and forces the water into the delivery pipe with a velocity more than the mean velocity. The quantity of water in excess of the mean discharge will flow into, in vessel. During second half of delivery stroke, the piston moves with retardation and velocity of water in the delivery pipe is less than the mean velocity. The water already stored in the air vessel will start flowing into the delivery pipe. Hence, the rate of flow of water in the delivery pipe, beyond the air vessel, will be uniform. The same reasoning applies to the air vessel fitted on the suction pipe.

Answer Key (Diagram if any)

G1.

Compare between centrifugal and reciprocating pump

Following table gives the comparison between centrifugal and reciprocating pumps.

S.No.

Centrifugal Pump

Reciprocating Pump

1.

Its discharging capacity is high

It can handle relatively small quantity of liquid.

2.

It is used for lifting highly viscous liquids such as oils, muddy and sewage water, paper pule etc.

It can handle only pure water or less viscous liquids free from impurities.

3.

It can be operated at very high speeds

It can be operated at low speeds only

4.

It can be coupled directly through flanged coupling to electric motor

These are mostly belt driven

5.

Maintenance cost is low

Maintenance cost is high

6.

It gives smooth and uniform flow

It gives pulsating and unsteady flow

7.

Installation is easy because of less number of parts.

Installation is difficult, because of more number of parts.

8.

Torque is uniform

Torque is not uniform

9.

It is very compact and occupies very small space.

it occupies 6 to 8 times that of centrifugal pump.

10.

Gross weight of the pump is low

Its gross weight is considerable

11.

No excessive pressure will develop even when discharge valve is closed.

If discharge valve is closed, very high pressure will develop causing damage to the pump.

12.

No air vessels are required

Air vessels are necessary.

13.

It needs priming.

It does not need priming.

14.

It can built up somewhat low pressures.

It can built up very high pressures

15.

At low heads its efficiency is high.

At high heads its efficiency is more.

16.

Less wear and tear.

More wear and tear.

17.

Practical maximum suction lift is 4.5 m.

Practical maximum suction lift is 6.5 m.

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

G2.

Explain the components of centrifugal pumps in detail

CENTRIFUGAL PUMPS

Centrifugal pumps are classified as rotodynamic type of pumps, which are used to raise the liquids from a lower to A higher level. The basic principle on which centrifugal pump works is that when a certain mass of liquid is rotate by an external force centrifugal head is impressed which enables It to rise to a higher level. Since in these pumps the lifting of the liquid is due to centrifugal action, these pumps are called centrifugal pumps'. A centrifugal pump is more suitable th,di a reciprocating pump for large discharge.

Component Part of a Centrifugal Pump

The following are the main parts of a centrifugal pump.

1. Impeller

2. Casing

3. Suction pipe with a foot valve and a strainer

4. Delivery pipe

Fig. 16.4 Component Parts of a Centrifugal Pump

Fig. shows the main component parts of a centrifugal pump

Impeller: It is a wheel which is fitted with a series of backward curved blades or vanes. The impeller is mounted on a shaft which is usually coupled to an electric motor.

Casing: It is an airtight chamber covering the impeller. It is designed such that the kinetic energy of the liquid discharged at the outlet of the impeller is converted into pressure energy before the water leaves the casing. The different type of casings that are commonly adopted are:

(a) Volute casing (b) Vortex casing

(c) Casing with guide blades

(a) Volute Casing: It is a spiral shape casing which surrounds the impeller. As shown if Fig., the shape of casing is such that area of flow gradually increases from the impeller outlet to the delivery pipe. Thus the kinetic energy is converted into the pressure energy

(b) Vortex Casing: If a circular chamber is provided between the impeller and the volute chamber as shown if Fig., the casing is known as vortex casing. The circular chamber is also known as whirlpool chamber. In this type of casing, the loss of energy due to the formation of eddies is reduced to a considerable extent.

(c) Casing with Guides Blades: In this type of casing, impeller is surrounded by a series of guide blades mounted on a ring as shown in Fig. The liquid leaving the impeller passes through the passage between the guide vanes. The passage has a gradually increasing area, thus reducing the velocity of flow through guide vanes and consequently increasing the pressure of liquid

Suction Pipe with a Foot Valve and Strainer: Suction pipe is a pipe which connects the sump with the pump inlet. The upper end of the pipe is connected to the center of impeller known as the eye of the pump. The lower end of the pipe dips into liquid in a sump.

The lower end of the suction pipe is fitted with a foot valve and strainer. The liquid first enters the strainer which is provided to prevent the debris (such as leaves, wooden pieces etc.,) entering into the pump. It then passes through the foot valve to enter the suction pipe. A foot valve is one-way type of valve which opens only in the upward direction. The foot valve does not permit the liquid to move downwards back to the sump when the pump is not working

Delivery Pipe: It is a pipe whose one end is connected to the outlet of the casing and other end delivers the liquid to the required height. A valve is provided on the delivery pipe to regulate the supply of liquid.

Unit VIII – Type the Question below

G3.

What is multi-stage pump? Explain with example

If a centrifugal pumps consists of two or more identical impellers mounted on the same shaft and are enclosed in the same casing, it is known as multi-stage centrifugal pump. Normally a pump with a single impeller is suitable for a manometric head upto 100 m. But if the liquid is required to be delivered against a still larger head, multi-stage pumps are used. In multi-stage pumps, all the impellers are connected in series so that discharge from the first impeller is guided into the inlet of the second impeller and so on till the required head is obtained. The stage of the pump is equal to the number of impellers.

Deep well pump (or) Bore hole pump

This is multi-stage pump, the -number of stages depending upon the head required. This is generally used for pumping water from depths greater than 8 m. It consists of a large diameter pipe extending from the bottom of well to the top. At the bottom is fixed a strainer with foot valve. Above it, a series of impellers are fixed one above the other for multistage action. These impellers are all fixed to a common shaft which is extended from them to the top of the well where it is connected to an electric motor. Sometimes, the pump; is driven by a prime mover, generally a diesel engine. In such cases a belt drive is employed for small and medium sized pumps and toothed gearing for larger sizes. In some types, the electric motor is fixed right above or below the impellers and are made water proof by suitable covering.

( Suction Strainer with Foot-Valve Pump Suction Pipe Non return Valve Regulating Gate valve Electric Motor Supporting Frame Raising main with shaft in it )

Fig. Deep well pump
